tasks.task: Integrate Isotonic Regression calibration into predictor
tasks.notes: Stage 3: Safety. Calibrates raw NN outputs to true probabilities (prevents overconfident bidding). Works standalone without ESMM towers. Math docs in gravity-main/esmm/PIPELINE_INTEGRATION.md §Stage 3.

tasks.task: Integrate MC Dropout for Thompson Sampling uncertainty
tasks.notes: Stage 4: Exploration. Multiple forward passes with dropout → variance estimate → Thompson Sampling with Beta distribution. Works standalone without ESMM towers. Math docs in gravity-main/esmm/PIPELINE_INTEGRATION.md §Stage 4.

tasks.task: Recursive cleanup: documentation, mathematics, and hoist config-driven system behavior (prod vs dev)

tasks.task: Implement online/incremental calibration updates as new data arrives
tasks.notes: Current calibration is static (fitted once from validation set). Options: 1) Periodic batch re-fitting (e.g., nightly cron), 2) Online isotonic regression (streaming updates), 3) Platt scaling with SGD. Need to decide frequency and cold-start handling. Related: calibration_real.json currently fitted from 1401 samples.

tasks.task: Quality test iterative learning ML system against design specs

Ensure feedback loops, exploration/exploitation, and online learning behave per spec.

tasks.task: Compare NN performance: 7,400 rows training vs 100,000 rows training

Measure: 1) Loss/accuracy improvements, 2) Calibration quality, 3) Prediction stability/variance, 4) AUC-ROC comparison. Document performance delta to validate data augmentation value.

tasks.task: Create Docker local dev container with UV + two-stage slim build for ARM/Colima
tasks.blocking: Consistent local development environment across team
tasks.notes: Requirements: 1) Single local dev container for gravity-main repo, 2) All Python packages installed via UV package manager, 3) Two-stage Dockerfile build process - first stage installs all deps, second stage creates slim production image with only runtime artifacts, 4) Must work with Colima as Docker runtime on macOS, 5) Target architecture: ARM64 (Apple M2/M-series chips). Consider: --platform=linux/arm64, uv pip compile for lockfile, multi-stage FROM python:3.x-slim-bookworm base, .dockerignore for build context, Colima VM resource allocation.

tasks.task: Investigate join loss: ad_clicks missing matching engine_events with ad_generated=true
tasks.blocking: ML training data ceiling - blocks scaling beyond 24K clicked samples
tasks.notes:
✅ RESOLVED - Issue was already fixed!

ROOT CAUSE IDENTIFIED:
• Total clicks: 53,892
• NULL grclid: 27,691 (51.4%) - ALL from before Nov 26, 2025
• NOT NULL grclid: 26,201 (48.6%) - ALL from Nov 26, 2025 onwards

CRITICAL DISCOVERY:
• NULL grclid clicks: Aug 6 to Nov 26, 2025 (historical)
• NOT_NULL grclid clicks: Nov 26, 2025 to present

VERIFICATION (Last 30 days):
• NULL grclid: 0
• NOT NULL grclid: 21,537
• Join rate: 100.0%

CONCLUSION: A code fix was deployed ~Nov 26, 2025 that started capturing grclid. The issue is resolved for new data. The 51% NULL is legacy historical data.

GOING FORWARD: Data quality will improve over time as legacy data ages out. New data has 100% join rate.

tasks.task: Analyze ad_generated flag: how many engine_events have ad_generated=false vs true
tasks.notes: Query: SELECT ad_generated, COUNT(*) FROM engine_events GROUP BY ad_generated. If most are false, investigate why ad_generated isn't being set. Check gravity-engine code that creates engine_events.

tasks.task: Analyze grclid coverage: clicks with NULL vs non-NULL grclid, and matching rates
tasks.notes: Queries: 1) SELECT COUNT(*) FROM ad_clicks WHERE grclid IS NULL, 2) SELECT COUNT(*) FROM ad_clicks c LEFT JOIN engine_events e ON c.grclid = e.grclid WHERE e.grclid IS NULL (orphaned clicks). Identify if grclid assignment is the issue.

tasks.task: Check table retention policies and data lifecycle for engine_events vs ad_clicks
tasks.notes: Investigate if engine_events are being deleted/archived on a different schedule than ad_clicks. Check Supabase policies, any cron jobs, or gravity-engine-workers that might prune data. Compare date ranges: SELECT MIN(created_at), MAX(created_at) FROM engine_events vs ad_clicks.

tasks.task: Trace click→engine_event flow in gravity-engine codebase
tasks.notes:
FOCUS NARROWED: The issue is NULL grclid (51% of clicks). Need to trace:
1) Where are clicks recorded? (gravity-engine click handler)
2) How is grclid supposed to be passed from ad serving → click tracking?
3) Why is it NULL for half the clicks?

Hypothesis: The grclid is passed via URL parameter or cookie, and something is dropping it for certain click paths (mobile? cross-domain? ad blockers?).

tasks.task: Share join loss impact analysis with stakeholders
tasks.blocking: Stakeholder awareness of ML data ceiling
tasks.notes:
Document: rtb-auction/docs/stakeholder/join-loss-impact-analysis.md

UPDATED: Root cause identified and issue RESOLVED.

Key points to communicate:
• Historical 55% data loss was due to NULL grclid (Aug-Nov 2025)
• A fix was deployed ~Nov 26, 2025
• Current join rate: 100.0% (last 30 days)
• Data quality will improve over time as legacy data ages out

Good news story - can share that the issue was proactively investigated and found to be already resolved.

- gravity-engine-workers/interface/product_embedder/main.py: output_dimension=2048

Options:
1. Update rtb-auction to use 2048 dimensions
2. Re-embed products at 384 dimensions
3. Add dimension reduction layer

Also note: rtb-auction uses collection 'ad_embeddings', workers use 'products' - need to align collection names.

tasks.task: Create bridge script: Python simulation generator → Go backend HTTP requests
tasks.notes:
Create bridge script: Python simulation generator → Go backend HTTP requests.

DEPENDS ON:

Bridge would:

tasks.task: Ask Leo for read-only production Redis access for simulation testing
tasks.notes:
Need read-only access to production Redis to test parquet simulation with live campaign/budget data.

Required Redis keys:
- `budget:campaign:{id}` - remaining balance per campaign
- `budget:daily:{id}:{date}` - daily spend tracking
- `user_campaigns:{user_id}` - cached campaign data from cache_refresh worker
- `pacing:state:{advertiser_id}` - pacing state (λ, spend, etc.)

This enables running local Go backend against real production budget constraints to validate pacing behavior with live data. Alternative to pure parquet replay.

tasks.task: Verify teammate's simulation flow matches documented Redis sync architecture
tasks.notes:
Teammate mentioned reading from Redis cache for simulation. Need to confirm:

1. Was he pointing local Go backend at production Redis?
2. Which Redis keys was he reading? (budget:campaign:*, pacing:state:*, user_campaigns:*?)
3. Was it read-only or also writing back?
4. How did he handle the cache_refresh worker sync (5-min TTL)?

Documented flow hypothesis:
- Production Gravity DB → cache_refresh worker → Production Redis
- Local Go backend reads real campaigns/budgets from production Redis
- Simulation uses actual budget constraints for realistic pacing

Compare with my parquet approach which uses static historical snapshot.

tasks.task: Register real Gravity campaigns in Go pacing controller from campaigns.parquet
tasks.notes:
Load campaign IDs and daily_budget from campaigns.parquet into Go pacing controller at startup.

Steps:
1. Create Python script to export campaigns.parquet as JSON (campaign_id, daily_budget, is_house)
2. Modify Go Internal DSP to load campaigns from JSON file on startup
3. Call pacingController.RegisterAdvertiser() for each campaign

Alternative: Create REST endpoint POST /api/v1/campaigns/register that accepts campaign data

Output: Go backend starts with 439 real campaigns instead of 5 mock advertisers

tasks.task: Modify parquet simulation to pass top_campaigns candidates in ad request
tasks.notes:
Currently parquet_to_go_simulation.py sends requests but Go backend ignores the Gravity campaign candidates.

Changes to event_to_ad_request():
- Parse top_campaigns JSON from parquet row
- Include as 'candidates' field in ad request payload
- Each candidate: {campaign_id, relevancy_score}

This gives Go backend the real Qdrant results without querying Qdrant itself.

tasks.task: Modify Go Internal DSP to use provided candidates instead of Qdrant mock
tasks.notes:
Go Internal DSP currently:
1. Queries Qdrant for ad candidates (or uses mock if unavailable)
2. Generates bids with mock campaign IDs

Change to:
1. If request.candidates is provided, use those instead of Qdrant/mock
2. Generate bids using the provided campaign IDs
3. Apply pacing (λ) from registered campaigns

Files to modify:
- services/internal-dsp/internal/service/dsp.go
- services/internal-dsp/internal/grpc/server.go

tasks.task: Wire auction wins to update pacing controller for real campaigns
tasks.notes:
Verify that RecordWin() in pacing controller:
1. Receives the winning campaign ID (real Gravity UUID)
2. Updates CumulativeSpend for that campaign
3. Recalculates λ (pacing signal)

May already work if REAL-001 registers campaigns correctly. Need to trace the flow:
Auction Engine → Budget Service → Internal DSP.RecordWin()

tasks.task: Add campaign name mapping to dashboard (optional nice-to-have)
tasks.notes:
Dashboard will show campaign UUIDs which aren't human-readable.

Options:
1. Load campaign names from Gravity database (requires Supabase access)
2. Use truncated UUIDs: 11f4348b... → '11f4348b'
3. Generate readable names from campaign index: 'Campaign #1', 'Campaign #2'

Low priority - UUIDs work fine for now.

tasks.task: Enable live Qdrant queries for new traffic (not just parquet replay)
tasks.notes:
Current approach passes pre-computed candidates from parquet's top_campaigns field. This works for replaying historical data but won't work for:

1. Live production traffic (no pre-computed candidates)
2. New ad requests not in the parquet

For production, Go Internal DSP needs to:
- Query Qdrant directly with user context embeddings
- Get real-time ad candidates
- This requires Qdrant populated with Gravity ad embeddings

Related: gravity-engine-workers/product_embedder populates Qdrant with ad vectors.

For now: Parquet replay uses pre-computed candidates (sufficient for testing pacing)
Later: Wire up real Qdrant for live traffic

tasks.task: Add Live Mode to stable-marriage dashboard (poll /api/v1/dashboard)
tasks.notes:
Dashboard currently shows pre-generated simulation data from /api/v1/simulation/history.

Need to add a 'Live Mode' toggle that:
1. Polls /api/v1/dashboard endpoint every N seconds
2. Updates metrics (λ values, spend, ROAS) in real-time
3. Shows actual Gravity campaign IDs (not mock adv-001)

This would let users watch λ values adjust as parquet simulation runs.

Alternative: Stream pacing updates via WebSocket.

tasks.notes: feedback-consumer: Kafka consumer for click/conversion events to update ML models. ml-inference: Serves NN value predictions (v̂) instead of heuristic eCPM. Both exist in rtb-auction/services but not wired into make demo.

tasks.notes: Multiple strategy lines on same chart (efficiency, spend, etc). Toggle which strategies to show. Color-coded: Lambda=purple, Ratio=blue, PID=green. Easiest to implement - extends existing charts.

tasks.notes: Select advertiser from dropdown, see how each strategy treated them. Shows spend trajectory, win rate, pacing signal for that advertiser across strategies.

tasks.notes: Show delta between two selected strategies. Green/red coloring for which is better at each time point. Good for A/B analysis.

tasks.notes: Matrix showing which strategy would have won each auction slot. Complex visualization - requires aggregating data across all strategies and time periods.

tasks.notes: Switch between SingleView (current), SplitView, and CompareView based on Redux state.

tasks.task: Create selector for extracting per-advertiser data across strategies
tasks.notes: Memoized selector that takes advertiserId and returns that advertiser's metrics from all loaded simulations. Aligns by timestamp.

tasks.task: Create AdvertiserSelector dropdown component
tasks.notes: Dropdown showing all advertisers from loaded simulations. Updates Redux selected advertiser state.

tasks.task: Create AdvertiserSpendChart with multi-strategy overlay
tasks.notes: Line chart showing spend trajectory for selected advertiser across all strategies. Color-coded lines.

tasks.task: Create AdvertiserDeepDive panel component
tasks.notes: Combines selector, spend chart, and mini KPI table for selected advertiser. Collapsible panel.

tasks.task: Create selector for computing strategy deltas
tasks.notes: Takes two strategy IDs, returns time-aligned array of differences for each metric. Positive = first is better.

tasks.task: Create DifferenceChart component (bar chart with +/- coloring)
tasks.notes: Bar chart showing delta over time. Green for positive, red for negative. Dropdown to select which two strategies to compare.

tasks.task: Add DifferenceChart to Tier 2 charts area
tasks.notes: Integrate into existing chart grid. Only visible when 2+ simulations loaded.

tasks.task: Create data aggregation logic for heatmap (time × advertiser × strategy)
tasks.notes: Complex aggregation: for each (advertiser, time bucket), determine which strategy performed best. Needs efficient bucketing.

tasks.task: Create StrategyHeatmap visualization component
tasks.notes: Matrix grid with color-coded cells. Row = advertiser, column = time bucket. Cell color = winning strategy. Tooltips for details.

tasks.task: Add StrategyHeatmap panel to dashboard layout
tasks.notes: Full-width collapsible panel. Only visible in comparison mode with 2+ strategies.

tasks.task: Refactor all relative imports to use @ path aliases (e.g., @/components, @/store) for cleaner imports
tasks.notes: Update tsconfig paths and vite config to support @ aliases, then convert all relative imports

tasks.task: Add time-bound awareness: auto-boost task priority as deadlines approach (e.g., trip planning rises as spring break nears)
tasks.notes: Approach: bash script + cron job that periodically pings MCP server to recalculate priorities based on deadline proximity. Consider prep lead times for reservations/planning tasks. NOTE: timeSensitive heuristic weight already exists in the scoring system - just needs to be wired up to decay based on real calendar dates.

tasks.task: UI Redesign: Consolidate Simulation Time panel INTO Simulation Control panel. Add play/pause/rewind/ffw controls, dataset file browser on right side, augment Run button.

tasks.task: Implement data source toggle: Pre-generated parquet files vs Streamed cloud data. Add config/UI selector and backend routing logic.
tasks.notes: Data sources: (1) Local pre-generated JSON from parquet simulations, (2) Live stream from Gravity cloud services (Redis/Kafka). Need env var or UI toggle. When cloud selected, subscribe to real-time pacing updates instead of file replay.

tasks.task: Create parquet streaming microservice with WebSocket output
tasks.notes: Go microservice that: 1) Reads parquet file row-by-row, 2) Applies pacing strategy (lambda/ratio/pid), 3) Streams events via WebSocket to frontend. Rate-limited to simulate real-time. Endpoint: /ws/stream?strategy=lambda

tasks.task: Frontend WebSocket consumer with live chart updates
tasks.notes: React hook to consume WebSocket stream. Append events to Redux store. Charts update live as data arrives. Shows current simulated time.

tasks.task: Implement event buffer for rewind/scrub capability
tasks.notes: SUPERSEDED: Original simple ring buffer approach replaced with comprehensive streaming performance architecture. See STREAM-PERF-* tasks for Web Worker + batching + downsampling + mutable refs approach.

tasks.task: Multi-strategy streaming (run Lambda/Ratio/PID in parallel)
tasks.notes: Single WebSocket connection streams all 3 strategies simultaneously for comparison. Each event contains metrics for all strategies on same auction.

tasks.task: Add tracking for which model generated each ad - some models may be significantly worse for adgen
tasks.notes: Teammate suggestion. Need to attribute ad output to specific models to identify performance variance across generators.

tasks.task: Explore Cursor RCP Server for opt-in contextual ad system - sponsored developer tool suggestions based on open files, AST, and project context
tasks.notes: RCP exposes: open files, project structure, editor selections, AST data. Product concepts: 1) Contextual sponsored suggestions (DB code → DB hosting ads, auth code → identity provider ads), 2) "Powered by X" integrations with free AI assistance, 3) Developer tool discovery based on stack. Value exchange: users get free premium AI features/credits in return. Ref: https://forum.cursor.com/t/whats-the-rcp-server-option-in-the-beta-settings/89697. Need to decide: standalone product vs integrate with existing Gravity ad infra.

tasks.notes: Diagrams needed: 1) Overall system flow, 2) Entanglement mechanism sequence, 3) Dynamic pricing tiers, 4) OpenRouter integration points

tasks.notes: Tool definition that Claude calls to fetch relevant sponsor context. Must be designed so Claude naturally weaves sponsor info into responses.

tasks.task: Implement verification callback endpoints (impression, click, conversion)
tasks.notes: Phase 2: POST /v1/verify/impression, /v1/verify/click, /v1/verify/conversion. These are critical for proving human engagement and enabling tier advancement. Without this, the bot/agentic loop protection doesn't function.

tasks.task: Implement basic tier calculation (CTR threshold, conversion tracking)
tasks.notes: Phase 2: Calculate user tiers based on engagement signals. Trial (5%) → Verified (50%, CTR > 0.5%) → Subsidized (100%, conversions) → Premium (payout). Key for self-correcting economics against non-human traffic.

tasks.task: Connect real sponsor inventory (replace mock SPONSOR_INVENTORY)
tasks.notes: Phase 2: Replace hardcoded sponsors.py SPONSOR_INVENTORY with real database. Could integrate with existing Gravity ad inventory or build dedicated sponsor DB.

tasks.task: Build partner dashboard (stats, tier status, revenue)
tasks.notes: Phase 2: Dashboard showing per-API-key stats: request count, CTR, conversions, current tier, revenue share. For pilot partners to monitor their traffic quality.

tasks.task: Follow-up with university to confirm 2027 intersession return is allowed for leave of absence
tasks.notes: Have copy of leave of absence form for 2027. Location: ~/Downloads/Leave of Absence Form.pdf on Framework laptop. Need to contact university in Fall 2026 to confirm return year of 2027 for intersession is permitted. Set deadline for October 1, 2026 to allow time before typical fall semester deadlines.

tasks.task: Create Web Worker for WebSocket connection and JSON parsing
tasks.blocking: All streaming performance tasks - single worker handles all WS messages off main thread
tasks.notes: Move WebSocket connection into dedicated Web Worker. Worker handles: 1) WebSocket lifecycle (connect/disconnect/reconnect), 2) JSON.parse() for all incoming messages, 3) Message classification (event/snapshot/complete/error). Main thread never blocks on network or parsing. Single worker is sufficient - WS is single-threaded anyway.

tasks.task: Implement batching in Web Worker (buffer array + 100ms flush interval)
tasks.notes: Worker accumulates events in buffer array. Every 100ms: 1) Batch all buffered events, 2) Compute latest metrics summary, 3) postMessage to main thread with {batch, summary}. This replaces the broken MIN_DISPATCH_INTERVAL=50ms throttle that was DROPPING events instead of batching.

tasks.task: Fix Redux slice - replace O(N) shift() with O(1) ring buffer using writeIndex
tasks.blocking: Eliminates array copy on every event when buffer is full
tasks.notes: Current addEvent reducer uses state.events.shift() which is O(N). Replace with: state.events[state.writeIndex] = event; state.writeIndex = (state.writeIndex + 1) % state.maxBufferSize. Also add bulkAddEvents action that accepts batched events from worker.

tasks.task: Implement downsampling for chart data (LTTB or time-bucketing)
tasks.blocking: Charts render ~200 points instead of 10,000 - critical for Recharts performance
tasks.notes: selectChartData currently maps ALL events (up to 10K) on every state change. Options: 1) LTTB (Largest Triangle Three Buckets) for visually optimal downsampling, 2) Simple time-bucket averaging. Worker can pre-compute downsampled data. Charts only receive ~200 points max regardless of buffer size.

tasks.task: Configure Redux DevTools for high-frequency streaming (actionsDenylist + maxAge)
tasks.notes: DevTools stores full state snapshot for every action. At 10 batched dispatches/sec with 10K event buffer = massive memory leak. Fix: 1) Add streaming/bulkAddEvents to actionsDenylist, 2) Set maxAge: 25, 3) Add env var DISABLE_DEVTOOLS for stress testing. Reference: store configuration in stable-marriage/frontend/src/store/.

tasks.task: Add mutable refs for full-resolution data (bypass Redux for raw event storage)
tasks.notes: For save/export functionality, we need full-resolution data but shouldn't pay Redux immutability cost. Create useRef for fullDataBuffer that worker populates directly. Redux only stores: 1) Connection state, 2) Downsampled chart data, 3) Latest metrics summary. Full data lives in ref for export.

tasks.task: Create architecture documentation with Mermaid diagrams for streaming system
tasks.notes: Document in stable-marriage/docs/STREAMING_ARCHITECTURE.md: 1) High-level flow diagram (Go → Worker → Main Thread), 2) Detailed component diagram showing Web Worker internals (ring buffer, batch timer, downsampler), 3) Main thread data flow (mutable ref vs Redux). Use Mermaid syntax for diagrams.

dataGaps.impact: CRITICAL GAP - eCPM = P(click) × P(convert|click) × payout
Replace SHA256 hash with real embeddings

decisions.rationale: Go backend is source of truth

decisions.decision: HTTP MCP server with JSON storage
decisions.rationale: Team rollout capability, simple start with upgrade path to SQLite

decisions.decision: REST polling for prod deployment (Kafka deferred)
decisions.rationale: Kafka + Flink in PRD is aspirational high-scale architecture for observability layer; REST polling via Go API sufficient for initial prod deployment. Kafka becomes relevant when needing stream processing at scale, event replay/audit capabilities, or decoupling for multiple downstream consumers.

decisions.decision: Adopt ESMM over separate CTR/CVR models
decisions.rationale: Eliminates Sample Selection Bias by training CVR on entire impression space via pCTCVR loss trick

decisions.decision: Conservative CVR placeholder: Gaussian(mean=1%, std=0.3%, floor=0.1%)
decisions.rationale: Industry programmatic display CVR is 0.5-2%. Conservative to avoid overbidding/budget exhaustion. Payout uses historic bid × 1000 scale factor.

decisions.decision: CVR parameters from real data: mean=2.39%, std=1.82%, floor=0.34%
decisions.rationale: Domain CVR statistics from 42 campaigns provided by colleague (Myles). Replaces conservative 1% estimate.

decisions.decision: ESMM model deferred to P2, pipeline components (Isotonic, MC Dropout) promoted to P1
decisions.rationale: Can build functional pipeline without full ESMM model. Calibration and exploration components work standalone.

decisions.decision: Completed tasks hidden from priority queue by default, toggle to show
decisions.rationale: Cleaner active queue while preserving completed tasks for history and V3 training. Use includeCompleted=true or ?all=true to see all.

decisions.decision: V3 ML: Start with XGBoost (Phase 2), defer Learning-to-Rank (Phase 3)
decisions.rationale: XGBoost handles tabular data well with small datasets. LTR requires more data and pairwise comparisons. Data collection now tracks: priority changes, task selections, queue state.

decisions.decision: Rename marketplace-design → rtb-auction, consolidate in gravity-main
decisions.rationale: All repos now live in ~/Desktop/gravity-main/. marketplace-design is now rtb-auction folder. Tasks referencing old name have notes indicating the rename.

decisions.decision: Migrated DynamicFloor (α price ceiling) from stable-marriage Python to rtb-auction Go pacing package
decisions.rationale: Completes INT-002. The α ceiling prevents infinite bidding wars while allowing budget fulfillment as deadlines approach. Formula: α = BaseCap + γ · max(0, GlobalPacingLag). Integrated into Controller.GetEffectiveBid() so all bids are automatically capped at α · v̂.

Creative/copy doesn't change between campaigns using same website. Pixel tracks all sessions on domain for baseline CVR. This is intentional "wide fish net" approach. Source: engagement_sync worker in gravity-engine-workers.

decisions.decision: Go codebase has multiple concerns (auction hosting, communication facilitation, experimental design) that could be split into separate microservices behind APIs in the future
decisions.rationale: Current monolithic structure works for now, but long-term maintainability and scalability would benefit from separation of concerns into distinct services

decisions.decision: Web Worker + Batching + Mutable Refs architecture for streaming performance
decisions.rationale: Frontend was crashing due to main thread overload: 1) JSON.parse on main thread, 2) Redux dispatch per event (1000/sec), 3) O(N) array operations, 4) DevTools storing full state history. Solution: Single Web Worker handles WS + parsing + batching. Main thread receives batched updates at 10/sec. Full-res data in mutable ref (bypass Redux). Chart data downsampled to ~200 points. DevTools configured with actionsDenylist.
